p: The difference between I. scapularis establishment and B. burgdorferi transmission risk should be taken into account; the ticks themselves do not threaten public health in the absence of B. burgdorferi and other tick-borne pathogens. To date, the establishment of B. burgdorferi in Canada has occurred following that of I. scapularis; however, the former lags several years behind the initial establishment of tick populations ( Ogden et al. 2010). A 5-year gap likely occurs between tick and B. burgdorferi establishment in Eastern Canada while a shorter, 3-year gap occurs in Central Canada ( Ogden et al. 2013). Also, tick phenology and the fitness of different B. burgdorferi strains may be affected by climate change ( Ogden et al 2008; Ogden et al. 2013; Moore et al. 2014; Monaghan et al 2015), but this analysis is beyond the scope of this paper.
